description:
Alistipes senegalensis is a species of anaerobic, Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, non-motile, rod-shaped bacterium that belongs to the genus Alistipes. It was first isolated from a human stool sample collected in Senegal, Africa, hence the name "senegalensis."

Alistipes senegalensis is a member of the phylum Bacteroidetes and the family Rikenellaceae. It is a strict anaerobe, meaning it can only grow and thrive in the absence of oxygen. The bacterium is non-spore-forming, which means it does not produce specialized structures called spores to withstand adverse environmental conditions.

Alistipes senegalensis is typically found as part of the human gut microbiome, the diverse community of microorganisms that inhabit the human gastrointestinal tract. It is believed to play a role in maintaining a healthy gut ecosystem and may have potential implications for human health, although its specific functions and interactions within the gut microbiome are still under investigation.

The genome of Alistipes senegalensis has been sequenced, providing insights into its metabolic capabilities and potential interactions with other gut microbes. Further research is needed to fully understand the ecological and functional significance of this species within the human gut microbiome.
